Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is development of integrated photonic platform based on single-crystal diamond and its application for realization of on-chip optical networks that operate over wide wavelength range from visible to mid-infrared. This will be achieved by fabricating optical devices (waveguides, resonators, etc) and systems directly into sub-micron thick single crystal diamond films. Several approaches to realize such thin diamond films will be explored. The research program will introduce diamond into the family of materials suitable for integrated, on-chip, photonics. In particular, diamond's strong third order nonlinearity and its excellent thermal properties will be leveraged to demonstrate low-threshold, high-output power, integrated diamond Raman lasers, as well as wide wavelength range frequency combs based on integrated diamond ring resonators.

This work will lay down foundations for the development of diamond photonics and its applications in diverse fields including quantum information processing, sensitive magnetometry, optoelectronics, life-sciences, bio-chemical sensing, gas spectroscopy, precision measurements, and high-frequency mechanical oscillators and switches. The research has strong educational components and will provide a unique opportunity to train students at all levels in interdisciplinary field that combines material science, fundamental physics, devices and system-level integration. Public fascination and familiarity with diamond gem-stones will enable engagement of wider audience. To achieve this, public lectures and presentation will be given at the Museum of Science in Boston as well as at local K-12 schools. The research has strong ties with industry and both diamond manufacturing and applications (e.g. oil industry). The international travel will enable key exchanges with UK firm which will provide high quality synthetic diamond substrates. The PI will also meet with researchers in Belgium and attend a diamond workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using diamond’s exquisite material properties, we have developed compact, on-chip, tunable laser source that emits at infrared wavelength range.

 

Our project started with the development of nanofabrication techniques suitable for realization of state-of-the-art optical components in diamond. This was challenging since high-quality diamond is not readily available in thin-film form needed for integration, and instead bulk crystals had to be used. To get thin diamond films, and enable on-chip integration, we sliced diamond into several 20 micron thick slabs. Then, we thinned these slices further, to around 1 micron thickness, using plasma etching technique similar to the one used by microprocessor industry, for example. Thin diamond films were then placed on a silicon chip with a layer of glass on top, and additional nanofabrication was done to carve ring resonators and waveguides inside them. Ring resonators are crucial for our work as they can trap light thus allowing a build-up of optical energy. Once enough light is circulating inside the resonator interesting nonlinear optical effects can take place. In this work we focused on so-called Raman process in which a fraction of input photons excites the carbon atoms that diamond is made of, and causes them to shake. This results in the loss of energy of the incident photons, resulting in their color to be changed, and shifted to longer wavelengths. Importantly, this process can be stimulated, by capturing the new wavelength-shifted photons in the same resonator, thus turning our diamond ring into a source of bright light of brand new color. This is called Raman lasing. In our work we used 1.55 micron light to excite the resonators, the same wavelength used for fiber-optics communications. Our laser produced light at 2 micron wavelength  - a color of interest for the next generation of optical communication systems that will feature wider bandwidth thus being to handle larger amount of data.

 

Diamond Raman lasers have been previously reported, but are typically made from bulk diamond crystals and macroscopic optical elements (big mirrors, large lenses, etc). Therefore, they are bulky, require careful alignment of components, may be susceptible to vibrations, and require large optical energy to operate. Our diamond Raman laser, however, is fully integrated and is by far the lowest operating power diamond Raman laser to date. Diamond also offers many advantages over other on-chip Raman lasers realized in other materials, including silicon and glass: diamond Raman shift is very large, much larger than that of silicon for example, which allows for large wavelength difference between pump and emitted light. This may enable generation of new colors of light at wavelengths that cannot be accessed otherwise. Furthermore, diamond is transparent across widest wavelength range, much wider than silicon, spanning ultra-violet, violet, infrared and terahertz. This allows for laser sources of many different colors to be integrated on the same chip. Such compact and broadband laser source could find applications in gas sensing, spectroscopy, wide-bandwidth communications, imaging and so on.

 

The future is bright for diamond Raman lasers!
